image.altText: Putin KGB zelenskyy composite

items.synopsis: Vladimir Putin had already proved himself NATO's greatest recruiter, and this week's summit in Lithuania highlights just how heavily sought-after the exclusive club has become, writes John Lyons.

title.children: How the NATO summit showed off Zelenskyy's power and the lingering fear of KGB ideals

image.altText: A 3D model of the building that burnt down in Surry Hills

items.synopsis: The century-old former hat factory caught fire on a Thursday afternoon. Within seven minutes of the first triple-0 call, the entire building, in the most densely populated part of Sydney, was an inferno.

title.children: Unravelling the inferno that reduced this century-old former hat factory to rubble

image.altText: An aerial view of houses in Hobart, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: Homebuyers are reporting an unregulated "buyer beware" market has led them to purchase homes with serious defects, even after pre-purchase building inspections. So what are the rules and what recourse do buyers have?

title.children: 'Luck of the draw' for potential buyers doing due diligence

image.altText: Christopher Eubanks raises his fist and grits his teeth at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Christopher Eubanks' dream run may have ended but he has a slice of Wimbledon history it took 30 years to conquer, while Aryna Sabalenka showed her power game is going to be extremely difficult to overcome.

title.children: American rewrites Wimbledon record books in defeat as Medvedev admits to 'dangerous' on court act

image.altText: A designed image showing John Zeitoune, Jye West and a building bearing an ACU logo.

items.synopsis: The Australian Catholic University has launched an internal inquiry after the ABC discovered the founder of the company providing its on-campus security has been charged with corruption — and had a secret business relationship with an employee overseeing its security contract.

title.children: Australian Catholic University accused of ignoring concerns about security contractor

image.altText: Huw Edwards holding a sheet of paper sitting at a news desk

items.synopsis: The BBC presenter facing allegations he paid a young person thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos is Huw Edwards, the BBC reports, citing a statement from his wife.

title.children: Huw Edwards named as BBC presenter at centre of scandal, police clear him of criminal offence

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Sarah Fisher wants to bring new life into the world but her fertility journey has been less than easy. Living off disability payments, she is struggling to pay for treatment and has spent thousands of dollars already only to be unsuccessful.

title.children: Sarah's rare disorder has meant her body has put up with a lot. She's now on a fertility journey but her fight isn't over yet

image.altText: Three children sit and play on electronic devices.

items.synopsis: New data from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission shows millions of consumers are paying more on power bills than they should.

title.children: Millions of Australian households paying too much for electricity, according to ACCC

image.altText: A car park at an outback resort with a red cliff in background.

items.synopsis: A resort west of Alice Springs will close while owners negotiate a water pipeline to be built from a bore 18 kilometres away.

title.children: Water costs render outback resort unviable in peak tourist season

image.altText: Josh Addo-Carry kicks

items.synopsis: A stunning solo try from the Fox, one just as good by the Hammer, and a return to form for some Blues favourites. Here's your five quick hits from State of Origin Game III.

title.children: Five quick hits — the Hammer and the Fox exchange super tries and Tedesco shows his class

image.altText: A man shapes to pass during a rugby league match

items.synopsis: An Origin dead rubber is what you make it, and on the back of barnstorming debuts and some brilliant returns, the Blues found a little hope for the future.

title.children: In barnstorming debuts and brilliant returns, the Blues might have found more than just pride

image.altText: Gender dysphoria

items.synopsis: One of Australia's leading medical insurers dumps cover for private practising doctors who initiate hormone treatment in adolescents with gender dysphoria, a decision that may put even more pressure on public hospital waiting lists.

title.children: Medical insurer drops cover for doctors who conduct hormone treatments in adolescents with gender dysphoria

image.altText: A woman wearing a bright yellow face mask look down at a nurse putting a sticker bandaid on her arm after a vaccination.

items.synopsis: Flu vaccine uptake in recent months across Australia is almost 2 million down on what it was last year, with experts blaming COVID 'fatigue' and cost-of-living pressures.

title.children: Flu vaccine uptake is down, and experts say COVID 'fatigue' and cost-of-living are to blame

image.altText: Two middle-aged men, one in a tight, olive green shirt and the other in a suit, shake hands in front of a woooden wall.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announces the commitment following a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the NATO summit in Vilnius.

title.children: 'Best in the world': Australia donates 30 more Bushmaster armoured personnel carriers to Ukraine

image.altText: A roadside sign reading "Peppimenarti" riddled with holes, on the side of a red dirt road.

items.synopsis: Michael Singar was arrested in 2022 after he confessed to fatally shooting a man with an arrow during a riot in the remote community of Peppimenarti. But after spending 109 days in jail, he was found not guilty.

title.children: Michael spent 109 days in jail for a crime he didn't commit. Lawyers say it's not an isolated case

image.altText: Huw Edwards stands at a podium talking into a microphone

items.synopsis: Huw Edwards has been identified by his wife as the reporter accused of paying a teenager thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos. Here's what we know.

title.children: Who is Huw Edwards, the BBC presenter accused of buying sexually explicit photos?

image.altText: A photo of a blonde toddler with a flower behind one ear

items.synopsis: Two-year-old Emile was staying with his grandparents when he disappeared from their tiny village.

title.children: Search for toddler who disappeared in the French Alps called off by investigators

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank branch in Melbourne's CBD

items.synopsis: The bosses of Westpac and Commonwealth Bank will face the parliamentary economics committee, a day after ANZ and NAB executives were grilled over interest rates. Follow live.

title.children: Commonwealth Bank and Westpac to face grilling over interest rates, US inflation slows, ASX to rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The second day of committee hearings into a review of the four big banks is getting underway in Canberra this morning. Yesterday, ANZ boss Shayne Elliott and NAB CEO Ross McEwa n faced the hearing yesterday, where they were quizzed about interest rates in the wake of the RBA's contractionary monetary policy, and what they're doing to combat scams. I'll be listening into the hearings today, along with my colleagues to bring you the latest from the Commonwealth Bank and Westpac bosses today. But if you want to get up to speed on yesterday's developments, my colleague Daniel Ziffer has you covered below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Missed the ANZ and NAB bosses being quizzed on interest rates and scams?

featuredLink.title: ANZ boss says half the bank's home loan customers have called to change their interest rate

children.content: The second day of committee hearings into a review of the four big banks is getting underway in Canberra this morning.
Yesterday,
ANZ boss Shayne Elliott
and
NAB CEO Ross McEwa
n faced the hearing yesterday, where they were quizzed about
interest rates
in the wake of the RBA's contractionary monetary policy, and what they're doing to
combat scams
I'll be listening into the hearings today, along with my colleagues to bring you the latest from the
Commonwealth Bank
and
Westpac bosses
today.
But if you want to get up to speed on yesterday's developments, my colleague
Daniel Ziffer
has you covered below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A new report shows the chief executives of publicly listed companies have recorded their lowest pay in the last nine years, with bonuses also falling from last year's record. The research, commissioned by Australian Council of Superannuation Investors, shows the average realised pay for CEOS of Australia's largest 100 publicly listed companies dropped from record highs seen in 2021 — likely because of tougher economic conditions and boardroom attitudes. In 2021, the investor group's research saw average CEO realised pay — which includes bonuses on top of base salaries — reached a high of 98 times the average weekly earnings of an Australian adult. Now, the average CEO pay has fallen, but is still 55 times higher than what the average Australian earns. "It is good to see more restraint on executive pay in Australian companies over the past year but there is still an 'everyone wins a prize' attitude in some parts of the market. Investors look for any bonuses paid to executives to be linked to the delivery of value to shareholders over the long-term." Ed John, ACSI's head of stewardship said. "Investors will be watching closely as reporting season gets under way and we see the numbers for 2023. It has been a choppy year for investors in many companies – boards will need to consider performance carefully when deciding on remuneration this year. "If performance is down in 2023, we expect to see bonuses follow. We don't want to see companies changing the goalposts when they have a bad year." Fixed pay for CEOs has also fallen in the past decade, with median fixed pay in the last financial year for the ASX100 CEOs coming in at $1,741,724.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: CEO paypackets fall to lowest level in nine years

children.content: A new report shows the
chief executives of publicly listed companies have recorded their lowest pay in the last nine years
, with bonuses also falling from last year's record.
The research, commissioned by
Australian Council of Superannuation Investors

, shows the average realised pay for CEOS of Australia's largest 100 publicly listed companies dropped from record highs seen in 2021 — likely because of tougher economic conditions and boardroom attitudes.
In 2021, the investor group's research saw average CEO realised pay — which includes bonuses on top of base salaries — reached a high of 98 times the average weekly earnings of an Australian adult.
Now, the average CEO pay has fallen, but is still
55 times higher than what the average Australian earns

"It is good to see more restraint on executive pay in Australian companies over the past year but there is still an 'everyone wins a prize' attitude in some parts of the market. Investors look for any bonuses paid to executives to be linked to the delivery of value to shareholders over the long-term." Ed John, ACSI's head of stewardship said.

"Investors will be watching closely as reporting season gets under way and we see the numbers for 2023. It has been a choppy year for investors in many companies – boards will need to consider performance carefully when deciding on remuneration this year.
"If performance is down in 2023, we expect to see bonuses follow. We don't want to see companies changing the goalposts when they have a bad year."
Fixed pay for CEOs has also fallen in the past decade, with median fixed pay in the last financial year for the ASX100 CEOs coming in at $1,741,724.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's been a long time in the making, but Elon Musk launched his AI startup overnight. The company, named xAI, aims to "understand the true nature of the universe", according to its website. It's not Musk's first venture into AI — he cofounded OpenAI (which is behind ChatGPT) but later left the startup, which has become one of the highest-profile companies in the AI space. But the Twitter owner has been wary of AI in the past, warning about its potential for "civilisational destruction" and a race amongst tech companies to develop it should wait until there's draft regulation for the sector. Musk's team has several former engineers and scientists from Google, Microsoft and OpenAI, and is actively recruiting for more technical staff. We can expect to hear more about xAI during a Twitter Spaces chat (where else?) on Friday, July 14 (local time).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Elon Musk launches AI startup  to rival ChatGPT

Musk's team has several former engineers and scientists from

, and is actively recruiting for more technical staff.

image.altText: Man in black shirt speaking with canon in the background

items.synopsis: The Federal Court had ordered the ABC to hand over documents that included the identity of a US Marine source, but the broadcaster refused to comply.

title.children: ABC drops defence in Heston Russell's defamation case to avoid revealing source

image.altText: Man standing at kitchen bench

items.synopsis: Patrick Quintal purchased a home in the Vicinity complex in Canterbury two years ago. Last week he found out it had "potential serious defects".

title.children: Patrick bought an apartment two years ago. Now he could have to pay nearly $200k for repairs

image.altText: A female AI news reader in a headscarf in a studio.

items.synopsis: Several countries across Asia are now welcoming AI news readers to their screens to present daily bulletins. Could Australia be willing to let digital bots pose as presenters?

title.children: AI news readers are becoming more common across Asia. Will Australia follow suit?

image.altText: A composite image of Carmy from The Bear, Shiv from Succession and Janine from Abbott Elementary.

items.synopsis: Australia's Sarah Snook is one of multiple Succession cast members to be nominated for an Emmy, with The White Lotus, The Last of Us, and Ted Lasso taking up the other top noms.

title.children: Join us as we chat snubs and surprises in this year's Emmy Award nominations

image.altText: A composite image of Hayao Miyazaki holding an Oscar statuette and the poster for New Studio Ghibli film

items.synopsis: Award-winning Japanese animation company Studio Ghibli is less than two weeks away from releasing its latest movie — without any trailers, promotion or even a storyline. Here's what we know.

title.children: Studio Ghibli's new movie is coming out in less than two weeks. They don't want you to know anything about it

image.altText: A smiling young man with a beard dressed in high vis pulls a beer from a tap from behind a bar.

items.synopsis: It's a long trek from anywhere, but Ongerup in Western Australia — population 114 — has a community that refuses to let the town die.

title.children: Why this small WA community banded together to buy the pub, supermarket, cafe and petrol station

image.altText: Andrew and Nicola stand side by side on the Perth foreshore

items.synopsis: One of Australia's richest couples announce their separation but insist there will be no impact on their shared ventures, including mining giant Fortescue Metals Group.

title.children: Mining billionaires Andrew and Nicola Forrest announce break-up, insist 'no impact' on FMG operations

image.altText: A blonde Japanese person smiles into the camera at a film set.

items.synopsis: The performer, whose real name is Ryuji Higa, was a media personality, model and activist.

title.children: Japanese influencer and LGBTQ advocate found dead in Tokyo office

image.altText: Beth Mooney

items.synopsis: The Ashes are tied up after a tense finish in Bristol, with Australia falling for just the second time in 42 ODI games.

title.children: 'The Ashes is on the line now proper': Series tied up as England hands Australia a rare ODI defeat

image.altText: Leslie Van Houten in prison blues wearing glasses in a courtroom

items.synopsis: In 1969, Charles Manson dispatched a group of disaffected young followers on a two-night killing rampage that terrorised Los Angeles. The killings remain etched in the American consciousness.

title.children: A Manson 'family' killer has been paroled but for many Americans those killings won't be forgotten

image.altText: Carol Sandland in a green shirt, looking straight at the camera out the front of a building.

items.synopsis: A nurse who was fired for sharing confidential patient information with the union says she did so because management at the mental health facility was not doing anything about staff safety concerns.

title.children: 'I thought it was legal': Sacked Canberra nurse defends leaking patient information

image.altText: Two people stand in front of a microphone, with blue sky behind them.

items.synopsis: Wakka Wakka man Dennis James Fisher had argued Indigenous people should be able to access the age pension at 64 instead of 67 due to the gap in average life expectancy compared with other Australians.

title.children: Aboriginal elder 'frustrated with white system' after court rejects his bid to access age pension three years early
